column1: This game has a lot of potential. I like its style and base mechanics. But it's hard to really see the good parts in this game right now because of some fairly dire problems:
1. Balance. There doesn't seem to be any kind of ""base rate"" these cards are built on. Like
column2: there's a card that increases shield capacity by 1 for 1 energy. Another card charges shields by 10 for 1 energy. Another card makes a 4/2 drone for 2 energy. There's also a card called ""AI Supremacy"" that gives you 10 shield capacity
column3: 10 shield charges
column4: and 4 4/4 drones. Going by the established rates
column5: this card should cost at least 19 (ignoring the fact that it also gives you all these effects in one card). Instead it costs 3. Yes it's ""mythic""... but that should mean it's maybe twice as good
column6: not 6 or 10 times as good. Having cards this strong makes your strategy and the enemy's strategy irrelevant - you just play your card and win. Things won't be perfectly balanced... but I feel like there could be a better attempt here.

column1: 2. Easy Exploits. Like Slay the Spire
column2: it feels like health is a resource that should slowly exhaust through a stage
column3: and most game mechanics here seem to suggest this was the plan. But there's a card that heals you and doesn't ""deactivate"". This means it's easy to kill all but one enemy
column4: shield up
column5: and loop through your deck until you're healed to full. I think there's one for credits too. You shouldn't be able to get these kinds of effects so easily (ie. with a single card and some patience). Learn the lessons of the other games in this space. These cards should exhaust.

column1: 3. Do-nothing events. Whatever is in the mysterious crate
column2: don't have it be nothing. Again
column3: I get this is early access... but I've played the game twice
column4: and it feels like I've opened 6 empty crates. Events don't need fancy graphics or something - just placeholder in _something_.

column2: if I was you
column3: dear reader
column4: and if I was looking for a game to play now - I'd add this game to my wishlist
column5: and come back to it once it has had a little more time to bake. But you shouldn't forget it
column6: because I think it could be good.";4.6;1.0;252.0;493.0;Posted: 28 March

column1: For the Warp provided a mixed experience which has some surprisingly involved card-driven space combat. However
column2: the hefty use of RNG gives it an unbalanced nature. One that is further complicated by a lack of mechanisms to limit its impact. Some gamers may find its content on the low side
column3: but it has been made to be replayed. Very likely the reason for its steep difficulty curve.

column1: For the Warp is a well made but unbalanced game. Strategic gameplay is good but could do with a few more additions and added variation. Tactical combat is at times an enjoyable experience with several viable strategies and synergies available. However
column2: the substance deck-building possesses is affected by a level of RNG that causes its overall difficulty to rise steeply

this game has a lot of great features and has some compelling gameplay. However
column3: there are three things that kill it for me because they lead too far down the path of heavy RNG.

column1: 1) The shuffler makes no sense. The fact that you don't discard cards and that every time you draw a hand that you are pulling from your entire deck is against the foundation of what a deck builder game is supposed to be. It has all of the other facets of how to build and manipulate your deck but the player should be drawing from a shuffled stack and continue to do such until the discard pile needs to be shuffled back in. I might have been less opposed to this if you could freely discard cards from your deck without needing to pay for it or have NPC's want to buy them during events. But as it stands
column2: it is far to easy to get a 18-20 card deck and that is far too much RNG when doing pool draws.

column1: 2) Draft mode is not worth playing due to the design of ships and certain cards. Each ship has a core deck archetype that goes with them. To top it off
column2: you are shown 10 cards to pick from
column3: then 9
column4: then 8
column5: etc. While this would certainly be what you would experience playing Magic: the Gathering
column6: the cards do not have enough synergy to interface with each other in this format let alone to build a half way viable starter deck that matches the ship you selected. Also
column7: you select the ship BEFORE you draft which should be the other way around. See what comes to you and what archetype you can build towards then decide what ship you want. The problem stated in #1 compounds this since you might not have that many shield cards and drawing them when you are getting blasted for 40 damage a round in the first map is not a good experience.

column2: there are certain cards you need to make your ship's archetype deck come together and there is no way to guarantee that you get those. As such
column3: it leads to runs that are destined to fail because you
column4: through RNG
column5: just don't power up your deck to the point that you can handle later encounters. Especially when you get screwed by not drawing what you need from your pool (see #1) for several turns.

column1: I like the premise of the game and it has a great foundation. Hopefully

column1: There are some interesting concepts here but some weird decisions that
column2: ultimately
column3: I didn't enjoy.

column1: * It's bizarre to me that you start with 3 cards instead of a full deck... No idea why that decision was made (but I'm assuming there is one...?) This means you'll easily take 9-27 damage (probably more later on) without being able to charge your shields or prevent damage (unless you get lucky with your draw on those first three cards) That's my biggest complaint
column2: really. I flew through the first system no problem but died within two encounters on the second system due to this mechanic.

column1: * I enjoyed the sci-fi spaceship/deckbuilding setting and the art is pretty good. Seeing the animations for the corresponding card you played is pretty cool. The backgrounds are bright and colorful and it's always fun to look at. The music was pretty great but seemed to be a bit repetitive?

* 'Burn' (think 'bleed' in other games - damage over time) doesn't take effect until the end of the enemy turn... which is a strange decision as well in my opinion. It doesn't allow the damage to be a real 'game-changer'. You'll take the enemy's attacks and THEN they die... which really hurts your momentum on a run since your HP carries over.

column2: I only played this for about 0.4 hours before dying and deciding I didn't enjoy it. It's possible that the game continues to open up as you progress (as deck-building games usually do) I want to like this game and will definitely keep an eye on it as it continues to progress through early access. If you like this genre of game you might really vibe with it... I'm sure I'll pick it up again in the future but I don't think it's something I want to play just yet.";0.4;0.0;0.0;507.0;Posted: September 14

column1: Synergies is an interesting concept. I like them to be honest
column2: and with the estimated 80 cards you're more likely to encounter synergy cards. It makes the actual deck-building fun
column3: and you can get some pretty interesting combinations. If you find an Ignite synergy with Nova Strike it's beautiful.

column2: I haven't messed around with this all too much. I have noticed that removing cards from your deck is a much more difficult process than adding cards to the deck. There's a few random encounters that allow you to remove cards
column3: and it's a beautiful sight that makes a grown man cry with joy.

column2: I would pick this game up if you like FTL and/or Slay the Spire. There's a few things that could deal with a bit of polish or reworking
column3: but otherwise it's a good game.

column1: Comparing this game to other FromSoftware products one aspect after another it’s clear that Elden Ring isn’t as smooth as Sekiro
column2: doesn’t have bosses like Dark Souls
column3: and its story isn’t as good as Bloodborne
column4: but looking this way at anything will make no sense
column5: you simply do not order salad in Subway and then put one star review saying that they refused to sell you a salad.

column2: Vaatividya still works on lore
column3: and so far we barely can piece together coherent explanation to what happened before we set foot in Lands Between. It offers some similarities to ideas that Dark Souls used before
column4: and it’s open for speculations as much.

column1: As for the story of the game
column2: we’re thrown in fractured world only hundred years after The Shattering
column3: war that no demigod came out victorious leaving Lands Between in stalemate.

column2: once stripped from the grace of Greater Will and exiled
column3: coming back to Lands Between
column4: resurrected and yet again guided by the very grace we were stripped from
column5: with one goal – to become the Elden Lord.

column1: To summarize how big Lands Between are I will say only this:
Elden Ring world is made up from five main parts on surface level
column2: this already sounds like enormous place. But wait
column3: there’s more – each part has legacy dungeons
column4: big structures that player can get lost for hours and still be surprised revisiting the place. There are also catacombs
column5: minor erdtrees
column6: ruins
column7: villages
column8: and so on. It is very densely packed and it gives hours upon hours of additional content to go through. Still not enough? There is literally 3 major underground locations
column9: each bigger than the last one. And for the dessert - whole legacy dungeon floating above the sea near the coastline of Lands Between.

column2: but is it pleasant to look at?

column1: To answer that we can go back and look at last two games made by FromSoftware
column2: Sekiro and Dark Souls 3
column3: and precisely Fountainhead Palace and Irithyll of the Boreal Valley. FromSoftware seems to like dragging players through countless swamps and catacombs
column4: difficult bosses
column5: and whatnot to build up the hatred towards another location that we might need to go through to finish the game
column6: and then every negative emotion leaves the body
column7: because we’re presented with what’s called ‘the best area in the game aesthetically’
column8: that’s the case with Irithyll
column9: that’s the case with Fountainhead palace
column10: and that’s the case with… nearly every legacy dungeon in Elden Ring. Progressing through the world of this game is like going the best location in one souls game to another best location from different game.

column1: I think there also is beauty in elevation
column2: and Elden Ring does exceptional job at that too. Lands Between are not flat
column3: they’re constantly changing elevation as we progress through the game
column4: but not only between main parts of the map
column5: also between locations in those parts.

column1: FromSoftware creates dark fantasy and I
column2: personally
column3: think that currently there’s no one in the industry better at doing so.

column1: The most important part for some
column2: especially if advertised as ACTION RPG. Just a reminder
column3: you’re Tarnished
column4: a nobody with a simple task to become the Elden Lord
column5: against various demigods
column6: with a stick and wooden shield. The game is not easy. It is not the hardest FromSoftware game
column7: but it’s still hard
column8: especially for newcomers.

column2: a lot. Elden Ring
column3: like any From game has no difficulty slider
column4: there’s one difficulty – Get Gud. Fortunately for Tarnished
column5: Elden Ring provides a lot of different mechanics to ease the pain such as: magic
column6: summons
column7: broken status buildup (bleed
column8: cold)
column9: co-op
column10: cheesing
column11: and last
column12: but not least (for PC) – modding. There already are mods to change the difficulty by lowering health and attack damage of nearly everything in Elden Ring. To experience the game the best way though is to go through it yourself
column13: learn to fight
column14: optimize your build and try again
column15: because there’s no better feeling in FromSoftware games than beating hard boss yourself.

column1: Will you get bored? I don’t think there’s a chance to get bored in this game

column1: Elden Ring is an open-world Action/RPG game
column2: emphasizing over-the-shoulder camera work behind your character

column4: but little space in this review to cover it all. It is easy to say ""Elden Ring is Dark Souls 4""

column1: Weight is the essence of Dark Souls design: your character has gravity
column2: many attacks are done in realistic ways
column3: fantastical magics exist but are limited in scope
column4: and the overall pacing is slow but gradual. In many respects it can be called 'low fantasy'
column5: emphasizing realism in much of what it does
column6: only to selectively break that for incredible effects. Those who are familiar with The Elder Scrolls series will also recognize this model of design.

column1: Elden Ring's art style reflects heavy western fantasy themes: grittiness
column2: decay
column3: but also beauty
column4: fantastical architecture
column5: and things both sane and bizarre
column6: all walk hand in hand together. While it is not pushing graphical realism to its hardest
column7: the distinct visual style delivers a consistent atmosphere to the world. Every area carries a theme
column8: purpose
column9: and vision that tells a story all of its own. In this respect
column10: Elden Ring happily uses environmental story telling in much of what it is.

column1: Varied musical scores and arrangements follow the almost purely instrumental sound track. Ambient pieces follow alongside epic arrangements for things like Boss Battles
column2: creating a dynamic landscape that is
column3: itself
column4: evocative of its world. Elden Ring's
column5: in my opinion
column6: hits pretty average with few notable outliers; all are worthwhile to listen to
column7: but few I went out of my way to make note of.

column2: itself
column3: the heart of all things Dark Souls; so all things are shaped by it. You are the Tarnished
column4: a no-name nobody
column5: misbegotten soul who returned to life. You are guided by a simple purpose: to overthrow the rulers of old
column6: acquire their power
column7: and establish yourself as the ruler of a new age. To do so
column8: you will travel through a dead
column9: dying
column10: or decrepit world on its last legs.

column1: As all around you succumb to the failings of the past
column2: you and few others are all that dare to change this gloomy status quo. How you will
column3: of course
column4: will vary. The end of one age brings forth another
column5: and so many forces that survived are vying to make it *their* new age. Who you help will have just as much an effect on the outcome of everything.

column2: Elden Ring and its Dark Souls siblings buries an entire world in its deep lore. Plot information scattered through items
column3: chance encounters
column4: one-off-lines by NPCs
column5: and the like. You are
column6: by design
column7: encouraged to sift through and recover these lost bits. To find out the 'truth' of what happened
column8: who these people are
column9: and the world they once lived in. You won't ever have a perfect picture
column10: but you will get one eventually. You could go all the way and know nothing at all
column11: if you so choose.

column2: Elden Ring did disappoint me in this regard. It is lockstep with its Dark Souls siblings
column3: showing zero innovation or change in how its plot delivers and NPC questlines work. This is especially frustrating as
column4: being an open world game
column5: an NPC could (and has) literally hide in the corner of the world
column6: 100% missable. Some will even die or disappear if you continue to play the game without finding them
column7: vanishing into smoke and never telling you that you failed to progress their questlines. I continue to regard this as an inherently bad design
column8: but using a wiki to find the information may spoil the quest lines.

column1: As you fight through the Lands Between
column2: you acquire runes
column3: the universal currency used for everything including leveling up. Through runes
column4: and gathered materials
column5: you can craft useful combat items
column6: talk to smiths to upgrade your weapons (armor doesnt need it)
column7: and level up to improve your overall power. Some varieties in play styles are present
column8: usually flavors of melee and ranged combat added together. Elden Ring as a whole favors melee
column9: and ranged is usually a supplementary style. Magic varies greatly
column10: but it is notably better than other Souls games in being a viable main class choice.

column2: I choose to criticize what is known as the 'Artorias' problem.

column1: A Super Boss from Dark Souls 1 DLC
column2: Artorias was outrageously popular as a 'mold' breaking boss
column3: being extremely fast
column4: tactical
column5: and responsive to the player. FromSoft has become addicted to replicating Artorias ever since
column6: putting his pattern behavior in many different bosses. This is especially notable in Elden Ring's late game bosses
column7: who all have insane response times
column8: massive damage
column9: and long windows of 'dodge or die' forced upon the player. Rather than be uniquely distinctive
column10: they all feel like different versions of Artorias. Thankfully
column11: many of the early and mid-game bosses didn't show this behavior
column12: and none of them were outstanding issues to me.

column1: I will make notable exception of Elden Ring's ""hardest"" boss:
Elden Ring is a good game
column2: and a worthy addition to the Souls family. Breaking off into its own narrative universe has interesting future implications
column3: as the Dark Souls storyline itself has been 'wrapped up'. As a combat-focused Action-RPG
column4: it delivers well on balancing real time attacks with the idea of making character builds and play styles. You need both in order to survive to the end.

column1: The open world design is perhaps surprising/welcome to newcomers
column2: but it is almost a perfect venn diagram of older Souls designs. Instead of long narrow tunnels that branch like a spider web
column3: you have big open fields instead. All the dungeons and the like are still there
column4: and are very classically Souls-like
column5: just much shorter in length. I don't hate this change of pace; better than many other games that try to become 'open world'
column6: Elden Ring (and Souls) feels perfectly in sync with it.

column2: personal note: I wish they did more with the storyline. FromSoft
column3: like Artorias above
column4: is addicted to their own formula
column5: and has shown zero variation or improvements. More in depth NPC questlines
column6: more creating of one's new 'ruling faction'
column7: and more of a world we can participate in
column8: are all things I'd like to see. Much of what you do in Elden Ring can be summarized as ""receiving a post-it note with instructions"" and exploring every cave you see in trying to finish those instructions.

Elden Ring asks the question: how would an open world Dark Souls work? And then answers it around 50 hours in: it doesn't. The world design and atmosphere are stunning
column2: but the scale of the whole game is simply too large to be filled with the limited gameplay it actually offers.

column1: The game counts almost single-handedly on your desire to scour the world for equipment as an incentive to drive forward and uncover characters
column2: lore
column3: and directional clues -- but character builds are centered around your equipment
column4: and 95% of what's in the (very
column5: very large and detailed) world isn't actually useful for the character you're playing. It's only compounded by the fact that most armour is balanced to be roughly equal
column6: and if you're counting on your exploration rewarding you with a cool new armour upgrade to replace your starter set
column7: you're going to be very
column8: very disappointed.

column1: This approach probably would have worked if the scaling of enemy rune drops was fine tuned
column2: with side bosses offering meaningful character level boosts so that if the piece of gear they drop is irrelevant
column3: the player still feels rewarded. Before long
column4: however
column5: I was playing for the charm and exploration for its own sake rather than gameplay itself -- a dangerous position for a very lengthy experience to find itself in.

column2: as always
column3: is quite good
column4: and some of the main boss fights (particularly the earlier story ones) were a hoot. Unfortunately
column5: the balance inevitably turns into a sort of glass cannon experience in which everything including you does high damage and has little health/armour
column6: so even major boss fights are quick and frustrating when you die
column7: and then punctuated by being over very quickly when you happen to get a good hit and win. In this way
column8: many of my wins felt like big anti-climaxes by midgame. I think if the game scaled damage down and reduced your available healing pool significantly
column9: it would make for slightly more drawn out battles in which putting in the effort to learn a boss's moves would be more rewarding
column10: and winning would be more satisfying.

column1: The other core element that translated badly to the large open world is the storytelling
column2: which stubbornly sticks to the traditional Souls-like formula of a detailed world with a threadbare plot that drip-feeds info and lore and leaves it to the player to interpret. That's all sort of interesting and works brilliantly in a tight
column3: semi-linear game with clear progression
column4: but in a vast open world I found myself needing some kind of dramatic tension
column5: sense of urgency
column6: personal stake or at least clear understanding of why I was doing what I was doing
column7: and Elden Ring doesn't deliver that sort of experience -- at least
column8: not where I'd gotten up to. I was disappointed to realise I'd had enough and become bored after clearing Limgrave+Liurnia+Caelid regions. From what others have said
column9: however
column10: the latter half of the game feels even more of a slog.

column2: the social element of leaving messages isn't really working well
column3: with the vast majority of messages being from mouthbreathers copying each others jokes about buttholes and Fortnite all around the map and presumably patting themselves warmly on the back afterward. The community sense of discovery and sharing
column4: which in some cases is essential due to the game's obscure design
column5: is greatly Tarnished by this
column6: such that toward the end of my play I was avoiding reading messages altogether.

column1: Elden Ring isn't a bad game -- it just isn't quite the big deal it wants to be. There's fun to be had here and it's probably worth grabbing the game and playing it through using a guide instead of trying to discover everything yourself and burning out. That said
column2: I think next time I have a hankering
column3: I'll be picking up Dark Souls instead
column4: and I'm not ""recommending"" this on balance.";106.3;0.0;7.0;111.0;Posted: May 8

column1: I really enjoyed this game. I'm a fan of FROM's games
column2: so while I was confident they'd make an good game
column3: I was worried that the move to an open world format would diminish some of their other strengths. I think instead they were able to show new strengths
column4: creating an open world that will be a new standard by which to compare others going forward.

column1: The gameplay is much like other FROM games
column2: though I did appreciate the effort they made to make it more varied
column3: and even in their own way make it more accessible through additional gameplay options. Between the many new options in this game like Spirit Summons
column4: and the resurrect ability in Sekiro
column5: you can tell FROM has been looking at ways of giving players alternative methods to overcome the difficulties in their games in smart ways that don't compromise their design and aren't a bland difficulty slider that changes the game globally. PVP seems to have improved feature-wise
column6: however the times I have played it I found it to suffer from a lot of lag. It's hard to tell if this is caused by players or the game
column7: but it's extremely common and makes PVP less enjoyable than it could be.

column1: I found the bosses to be overall easier than in previous games
column2: with some notable exceptions where it seemed FROM was almost making a point to show they can still make a hard as hell boss fight when needed.

column1: The world design makes incredible use of scale
column2: and the areas have a good amount of variety
column3: both in terms of types of environment but also in terms of the enemies within and the content density. The first few areas are packed with places to explore and things to find
column4: while some of the latter areas are a bit more sprawling and sparse. I didn't care for some as much as others
column5: like the blinding snowfield
column6: but with so much
column7: that's bound to be the case. The enemy variety is worth noting too. Someone recently counted them up and found that Elden Ring had more enemy types than Breath of the Wild
column8: AC: Valhalla
column9: Ghost of Tsushima
column10: and Horizon Forbidden West combined.

column1: The emphasis on open world does mean a bit of a step down in terms of the small scale level design. Many of the past games
column2: Dark Souls 1 in particular is renowned for its incredible interlocking vertical layered approach to the world. Elden Ring does have a bit of this in spurts in areas the community has taken to calling Legacy Dungeons
column3: but not quite to the same extent.

column1: The graphics are a huge step up in quality for FROM. Basically look at any screenshot of the landscape and it would probably make an amazing wallpaper. FROM has always had a good artistic eye for presenting the player with interesting focal scenes
column2: and having an open world just allowed them to do that all the more. Characters designs are largely the same as past games. Passable
column3: but not their strong suit
column4: particularly with the faces. And as ever
column5: the character creator is very difficult to work with
column6: perhaps even the hardest boss in the game.

column1: The UI is very much a FROM software UI. There are some quality of life improvements
column2: like sorting and some better presentation of information
column3: but it is what it is.

column2: but for all the variety I kept hoping there would be more. Maybe it’s a case where there's just never enough
column3: but knowing how big of a deal fashion is
column4: I keep hoping they'll lean into it more. The armor alteration system is interesting
column5: but it almost feels like it wasn't fully fleshed out
column6: as in most cases (with some notable exceptions)
column7: it's just about removing the cloak. In the future
column8: at the least
column9: it would be nice to see color palette changes as an additional option.

column1: As far as the lore of the world goes
column2: this is probably the best realization of FROM's style of presenting lore in the abstract but discernable through the world and items you find
column3: and the lore of this world is very interesting to learn about as you go through the game.

column1: Quests are a bit of a mixed bag. I enjoyed the content of the quests
column2: such as there is. I'm not opposed to FROM's typical minimalist quest design. FROM tends to not treat quests as traditional RPG quests
column3: but more as fleeting ephemeral experiences with characters
column4: and things you do in the world may or may not advance your relationship with them
column5: much like life. I get that. However
column6: there is also a good argument to be made that it's still a game. At the very least if you're going this route
column7: with a system where the conditions for advancement are not transparent
column8: then you need those quests to be reliable
column9: flexible
column10: and bug free
column11: and I feel like in the game's current state this is lacking.

column1: Many times there are quests that behave in unexpected ways
column2: or only via exceedingly strict conditions. For instance
column3: I had one quest that would not advance until I had rested at one specific site of grace. No other site of grace would do
column4: and this one was not obviously associated with the events. I had another case where a bug preventing a character from speaking with me
column5: that had me spending time trying to figure out what I was missing (fortunately this was fixed in patch 1.04).

column1: I kind of wonder if a lot of the non-mainline quest content was added at the very end of development and that's the cause of these issues. I get that feeling because even as of the most recent patch
column2: new stages to quest chains are still being added
column3: which is pretty unusual. Unfortunately
column4: combined with the previous issues
column5: this also leads to problems. There is one new quest line with a new character announced in the patch notes that I am unable to even begin because of a non-quest related action that I took before they were added to the game. In short
column6: I'm open to the way FROM designs quests
column7: but I think they fell short of what they were going for.

column2: these complaints don't detract from the overall experience which is still pretty amazing. I highly recommend this game and look forward to future DLC.";255.8;1.0;2.0;1876.0;Posted: May 9

column1: Online experience is really good. Coop is really fun. Mixing up moves and supporting each other in fights is really good. I would even say it makes the game a bit easier

column2: there are downsides to the game too. Some invaders are super laggy

column1: It's hard to describe why Elden Ring is so
column2: so good.
it's so incredibly easy.

column1: Why? We just need to look at the core attitude of Elden Ring
column2: from a design-to-player perspective.
that much is clear. But it's not to laugh at you or to discourage you.

column1: It's hard because it knows what you're capable of
column2: and it believes in you. It doesn't want you to give up.

column1: Despite killing you all the time
column2: it respects your intelligence and holds you of the highest regard. Elden Ring wants you to succeed
column3: and this gives it the framework to do so many things right.

column2: Elden Ring does hold your hand in many aspects
column3: than past games. but The story and lore of the world will completely pass you by if you don't take the time to read item descriptions
column4: examine the world
column5: and talk to every NPC you meet. You will be torn apart if you don't take the time to familiarize yourself with your weapon and shield. Most of all
column6: if you don't take your time
column7: you will be seeing YOU DIED a lot as well. The game grounds itself in patient manner when it comes to enemies and bosses: it wants you to slow down
column8: weigh all of your options
column9: experiment
column10: and most importantly do whatever it takes to survive.

column2: but weighty; everything about the fighting is spot on. Small weapons swing fast like they should. Large weapons swing slow
column3: and when they hit the ground they emit satisfying ""clunk"" sounds. Every swing depletes a certain amount of stamina. It's a simple mechanic but it puts so much choice and consequence on the player. You can try to attack like a madman to burn your enemies down as fast as you can
column4: but you won't be able to hold a block with your shield if you run low on stamina. All of this goes double for the intense boss fights - most of the bosses won't hold anything back and they will be a true test of applying everything you've learned thus far. You will die
column5: a lot
column6: but finally defeating one of these bosses grants you such an immense feeling of accomplishment
column7: because YOU DID IT ALL WITH YOUR OWN SKILL!

column1: The world of Elden Ring is completely open world. There are very few loading screens
column2: there are no transitional airlocks between areas; everything is seamlessly connected to each other. At times
column3: the geography will seem strange but once you take a look around and realize that you can actually see areas from other places
column4: suddenly everything feels natural. Elden Rings' atmosphere is done with careful and precise attention. Fromsoft uaed veryvspecial techniques with the color wheel to get every area perfectly.

column1: At times you'll be exploring dark
column2: moody caverns
column3: other times you'll be wading through a dense
column4: moonlit forest with nothing but the ambience to accompany you. Sometimes you'll even find yourself deep in the middle of a trap filled fortress. Make sure you always have your wits about you and you're actively paying attention. The world is just flat out beautiful and knowing that the game is one big connected overworld makes it feel so real and alive
column5: and it really drives home the sense that this world is huge and it brings back that ""adventure"" experience I've come to miss so bad. The world is yours
column6: and you're free to go wherever you please. At times
column7: you might feel like you're a bit lost
column8: and I do admit the game is sometimes a little obscure with the regard of pointing you towards the right direction
column9: but there are subtle clues and hints. Are the enemies too hard in a certain area? Is there a locked door? There's probably another way you haven't explored yet.

column1: The world is also home to many NPCs. I mentioned before that if you don't take the time to talk to the NPCs you meet and try to piece together who they are
column2: what they're doing
column3: and how they got where they are
column4: you're going to miss out of a lot of Elden Ring' story. This is where I feel Elden Ring' thematic focus comes full strength. The entire game is about overcoming
column5: and fighting through your own struggles. In that same sense
column6: all of the characters you meet along the way are also fighting for something. Something they thought was important
column7: or something they hold dear. Really
column8: take the time to get to know these people and pay attention as well. You won't know where they go next if you don't listen! With that said
column9: if you make the effort to witness each of these stories
column10: you'll watch them struggle along with you
column11: fighting their own battles. Yes
column12: DElden Ring is rich with lore and backstory
column13: but I think the real beauty is watching these characters fight for what they believe in
column14: while you yourself are fighting your own battles too.

column1: Elden Ring also has a very unusual multiplayer system. At all times
column2: your character will be in either one of two forms: Tarnished or human. This enables you to partake in jolly co-operation! If you're in an area where you haven't beaten the boss yet
column3: you can summon fellow players to your world who are also in the same area
column4: as long as they're relatively near your soul level. Sounds good right? Just like the combat
column5: there's another consequence you might have to face when you turn human. Elden Ring allows players to ""invade"" the worlds of other human players. They will appear as red phantoms
column6: and they will hunt you down and kill you on sight
column7: essentially marking this game's version of PvP.

column2: this is where I feel Elden Ring' biggest community strength comes from. You see
column3: once a player invades you
column4: all bets are off. They might be insanely twinked out. They might be a fair fight. They might want to honor duel you. You might even have a couple friends already summoned to help you out. Some players have taken it upon themselves to create a sort of ""honor"" code when it comes to PvP. They like to designate certain areas of the game for official dueling
column5: with no help from other players or no healing
column6: stuff like that. Some players agree with doing this. Some players prefer the chaotic nature of invading in random places
column7: not knowing what either party will be up against. Some players are firmly rooted in the idea that PvE and PvP should not intertwine.. What ""honor"" or ""etiquette"" should be included in Elden Ring' PvP
column8: if any
column9: is still being debated today. I feel like there will never be one solid answer but I think that's okay. It allows for more discussion and I think there's something inherently beautiful about a community being on two complete opposite sides of how an in-game mechanic should work. Bottom line: try
column10: at least a couple times
column11: to play through the game in human form. The invasion mechanic is a part of the game
column12: and even though sometimes you'll get ganked
column13: it's an experience quite like no other.

column4: LEGEND
column5: SOMETHING BADASS"" to ""EASY
column6: CASUAL
column7: SOMETHING NOT SO COOL"" based on what the game designers feel the tone of the game should be From Software instead created an open world where even though the start of the game feels like any other souls game (walk three steps...and...

column9: From Software says ""Hey

column12: but also kind of fight things for you. In the end it just comes down to how hard or easy you want the game to be. I personally found myself constantly making the game easier even though I knew I could beat it without those functions which lead to frustration
column13: but that's just me. I know some players personally who either don't have the capacity or the willpower to torture themselves like I do so those functions make the game enjoyable for them. Besides the items and the world they've also removed single player invasions so players can take their time exploring and farming runes without random invaders appearing and sending their sou---runes to the abyss. I feel like sometimes doing your own thing can lead to great things and From Software has proven that you really don't need to follow all the trends and do things like others do to appeal to the masses (or perhaps old men in black suits). Sometimes siting down and improving how you already do things results in a far better outcome and Elden Ring proves that.

After beating Elden Ring in roughly 85 hours (I tried to do as much side content as possible)
column2: I find my thoughts on it very scattered and conflicting. This makes deciding whether to recommend it or not very challenging because a recommendation is a very binary thing
column3: either you should or should not spend your money on it. In the end
column4: I’m going to give it a thumbs down not because I dislike it or because I think it’s a bad game but because it is a phenomenal game that is fundamentally flawed to the point where it will ruin enjoyment for all but the most committed Dark Souls fans. Apologies
column5: this is going to be a bit of a ramble so if you’d like to see if it’s worth reading or you’d like a TL;DR skip to the end.

column2: the game is visually stunning
column3: not to the level of the Demons Souls remake mind you
column4: but stunning nonetheless. The vistas and overall world design present that of a land worth exploring. It is one of the few open world games I’ve played that take advantage of the world it exists in. The combat is very well polished and is a straight improvement from the already streamlined Dark Souls 3 with the addition of jumping attacks and even more unique weapons and spells to play around with. “Vitality” as a stat has been removed and equip load and resistances have been baked into “Endurance” again which itself has been nerfed because stamina and stamina regen are much more forgiving in the game making it a less necessary investment than it was in the original Dark Souls. The first third of the game is much more welcoming to new players
column5: more than any other Souls game I’ve played and the reason for that is because of the open world design. “Easy mode” in Dark Souls has always been the leveling system. The more you explore
column6: the more experience and skill levels you get to make later fights easier
column7: and Elden Ring expands upon that with its open world. In a game like Dark Souls 3
column8: if you can’t get past Dancer of the Boreal Valley there’s not much else you can do besides continue slamming your head into a wall until you win or give up. In Elden Ring
column9: every main boss can be avoided temporarily so if you don’t feel confident in taking them on at your current level you can go explore elsewhere and feel like you’re making progress.

column2: and here is where I’ll start to go into the negatives
column3: this design philosophy is the seed from which many of my problems with the game evolve from. Because of the freedom to choose where to go
column4: many things get very difficult to balance very quickly. It’s hard to craft rewards and challenges the always meet the player at where they currently are in their leveling. Boss difficulty is an obvious example
column5: but another even more impactful one is the rune economy (experience for leveling up)
column6: which is frankly
column7: completely bananas. There’s no telling if an enemy will give you 100
column9: or 10000 runes. Whereas in other games where the more difficult the challenge
column10: the greater the reward
column11: in Elden Ring it feels completely random. This problem also exacerbates the variations in skill level people will be at in different parts of the game. So
column12: if you play like me and want to explore every cove and mountain
column13: which the game encourages you to do
column14: you will be incredibly overleveled for the first two-thirds of the game and difficulty will be most sapped out of it. Pair this with the fact that while the world is huge and varied the enemies and most especially the bosses are not. Catacombs
column16: and mines are fun until you realize 90% of them have repeat bosses or basic enemies scaled up to boss level health and damage. Hope you like fighting the watchdogs because you will fight that boss around 30 times whether as bosses or just basic enemies. Hope you like fighting dragons too. First time you encounter one drop on top of you it is incredible and tense
column17: once it happens to you 10 more times it stops being that way. These are not one offs. There are
column19: around 10 bosses that are repeated more than 5 other times in the game and probably 50 other bosses more that are repeated at least once. You find out very quickly that most of the work on boss design went into the dozen or so core story bosses which
column22: Radahn and Malenia are phenomenal imo. There are some troll and gimmick bosses but every Souls game is allowed a couple. My main issue is just because of the size of the game
column23: they feel obligated to overpopulate the land with bosses but without the time to properly flesh them out so they just end up being a reskin of another boss making it tedious. The sad thing is that it cheapens the really good boss fights and doesn’t let you set your expectations about whether the fight is going to be a memorable duel to the death or another snoozefest against a basic enemy you’ve fought 20 times before.

column2: I would be remised if I did not mention the Mountaintops of the Giants and the end-game difficulty spike
column3: which is plainly ridiculous. I have probably close to 1
column4: 000 hours overall in every Dark Souls game including Demon’s Souls
column5: Bloodborne
column6: and Sekiro
column7: and this is by far the craziest difficulty spike I’ve experienced. It’s like they combined Frigid Outskirts from Dark Souls 2 and Hunter’s Nightmare from Bloodborne and turned it up to 11. You have to constantly be on your guard at all moments. Pretty much any medium sized basic enemy from this point forward in the game can 1 or 2 shot you. The AI summon system
column8: which up until this point felt like the true “Easy Mode” basically becomes a necessity. Bosses will 1 shot you with 70 vigor (close to the max health you can get). Enemies from the early game reappear with 5 times as much health and damage
column9: while you’ve already reached your softcap in vigor and damage meaning there is no leveling around this problem now. It’s certainly doable
column10: even without summons which is what I limited myself to during the bosses but god help new players who don’t have the experience or time to build in the reflexes.

column2: I guess I could sum up my opinion on Elden Ring by saying it is simultaneously the easiest and hardest Dark Souls game and also ultimately
column3: the best and worst Dark Souls game. This is simply due to the fact that it is so large and unwieldy that it is bound to have a lot of hits and misses. There are times in the game where you will think this is the greatest game ever made and other times where the level and enemy design is so bad you question whether or not it was even play-tested before release. Many of the problems I have with it
column4: the rune economy
column5: varying boss difficulty
column6: over/under leveling
column7: AI summons
column8: copy pasting bosses
column9: all evolve from the premise of the game being open world. So
column10: while I agree with the fans that the open world is well crafted and probably one of the best a major game studio has developed
column11: there are clear fundamental problems that need to be addressed with the “Open-world Dark Souls” formula if they are to continue down this path and make a sequel. If you still would like to experience it
column12: I think it ultimately is worthwhile but something I personally will not be repeating for quite some time.";92.9;0.0;5.0;126.0;Posted: May 8

Titanfall 2 is just fantastic. A campaign that is more than just an enjoyable adventure
column2: it features constantly evolving mechanics always surprising you with new twists and exciting things to do. It brings a freshness I haven't seen since Portal 2
column3: while keeping the length at ""just about right"".

column1: There's genuine effort put into the plot and level design of what could have otherwise been a barebones story thrown in as a tutorial for the multiplayer mode. Instead
column2: what little I heard of it made me check the game when I had no interest whatsoever in trying its multiplayer aspects. And I'm glad I got on this ride because it was such a fun romp!

column1: While you can see most of the story outcomes (including the ending) come from a mile away
column2: the moment to moment parts are crafted so well that it won't matter how predictable things are. Your character goes from low rank infantry trooper to an experienced mech pilot through the many gauntlets the story throw at you
column3: and they are all glorious
column4: memorable set pieces that vary the gameplay just enough
column5: while introducing all sorts of charismatic villains to face off in such clashes.

column2: the bond between the main character and the Titan's self-learning AI (nicknamed BT) grows slowly but noticeably and -- silly as it may seem -- that too becomes a highlight. From initially addressing the MC as a disposable ""Pilot""
column3: to ""Cooper""
column4: and eventually to first name basis ""Jack""
column5: it's a scene with meaning and heart when BT suddenly turns to the MC and says ""trust me"" like an actual battle comrade would instead of just silently proceeding with the mission.

column2: this too is a standout experience that differentiates Titanfall 2 from other shooters. With a fluidity and precision that are so seamless
column3: you end up pulling whatever creative moves you can think of. Wall walking
column4: double jumping
column5: the stealth mode strafing
column6: the absurd selection of weapons available to loot from the different militias (each weapon with its own distinctive feel)
column7: it all comes together to form a frantic parkour-infused action package that somehow manages to stay elegant at all times. And that's you playing as a soldier on the ground! The moment you embark on your humongous mech
column8: the world changes
column9: the tiny people in the ground trying to shoot are insignificant and only the brutal clashes against other Titans matter. It's satisfying how those two completely different realities coexist so well together.

column2: a shame that the likelihood of a sequel of this quality is unlikely to ever appear.";7.7;1.0;11.0;2378.0;Posted: 11 May

Another console game with absolutely terribly ported controls. Can't even get into it
column2: dealing with annoyances every few seconds from the very beginning.

column1: - Movement is bad - It is designed for a controller stick
column2: not a keyboard. This means that your character will randomly start running a circle or running off to the middle of nowhere instead of going where you are pressing. The same applies to the horse. While riding with your group
column3: he suddenly starts running a big curve away from everyone or backwards and then you have to fix it and catch up.

column1: - Volume is quiet - This is a known bug
column2: really had to boost all my volumes to hear dialogues. This is particularly annoying when the camera is far away as volume is also tied to distance from characters.

column1: - Camera is bad - To get around tragic horse controls while trying to ride with someone
column2: you can toggle cinematic camera by holding V
column3: which causes the horse to follow the path on autorun (no other way to do it). You can then cycle through different angles/distances with C. The problem is
column4: the game doesn't respect your choice. Even when you set it up just how you want it
column5: within 5-10 seconds the game will switch to something else and you have to cycle through everything again to fix it. This means you miss half the conversations
column6: because the camera suddenly zooms far away. The camera also can't be freely turned in this mode
column7: so you end up missing all the scenery because it is aimed at the ground or some tree on the side instead of anything meaningful.

column1: - Button holding - Every interaction needs a button hold
column2: not a button press. There is no PC game that does this. There is no toggle for it. This makes everything you do painfully slow and super annoying.

column1: - Animations are slow - Everything from walking to picking up items is like a grandpa doing it. In terms of looting chests
column2: you need to hold the button per every single item you pick out and wait for the whole animation to play out. Needless to say
column3: every chest will take you quite a while.

column1: - Keybinds - The game uses half your keyboard for no real reason. Most games use either E or F consistently for every interaction. This one can't even decide whether looting alone is E or R because it uses both randomly so you have to constantly pay attention to the prompts
column2: completely breaking any immersion.

column1: - Saving - This is the first game I've ever seen that doesn't have the Save button in the main menu. It is buried in a submenu. Had to google to find out how to save. Not that it matters
column2: because the game pretty much always stops you from saving manually anyway. Already annoyed by this as I tested the game when I got it and quit to continue the next day. Had to rewatch the whole intro and skip the 4-5 cutscenes manually one by one when they finished loading before I got back to where I was.

column1: - Rockstar launcher - Great way to slow down loading of a 100+ GB game by another 30-40 seconds.
I haven't even gotten that far
column2: but you can't go few seconds without being annoyed by all this. Almost feels like they never played a game before. In terms of Quality of Life features
column3: this game has none.";2.0;0.0;5.0;242.0;Posted: 13 May

column1: Below Zero takes everything that was captivating and amazing about Subnautica and blatantly disregards it in an attempt to break new ground with a new story.
Every individual component of the game is executed worse than the previous iteration.
The story is the least disappointing part
column2: except for the part where you've already figured out everything about halfway through. There are no surprises
column3: no twists
column4: no turns. Character vignettes are surprisingly well done
column5: and they did a good job making the unseen cast have their presence felt. The decision to voice the protagonist and give them their own spoken narrative... obliterates the storytelling whenever she speaks up. She's not very relatable
column6: and her dialogue is mediocre most of the time. The VA performance is great
column7: from her and the rest of the cast. But it never stops being jarring every time she speaks
column8: and really breaks the feeling of isolation and tension. I want to feel like I'm uncovering something spooky and mysterious
column9: and it's impossible to do that if every time I find something notable
column10: the main character pipes up to give commentary that often doesn't fit the mood of the player at the moment.

column1: Locations are a nightmare. The world map is broken up in such a way that you find yourself doing mostly ""dead-end"" journeys. You venture out to an area
column2: and have to go further and further into it until you find what you were looking for
column3: and then retrace your steps methodically to leave. There are few interconnections
column4: most locations only have one way in or out
column5: with tons of dead space between their entrances and where you need to go. You will constantly be backtracking your way out of the same places you've been. Cave networks are more convoluted and devoid of landmarks that make navigation palatable. You can expect to run in circles wondering if you've actually explored the breadth of an area
column6: because the one branch looks identical to the next.

column1: Creatures are mostly underwhelming. Most of the ""enemies"" can be safely disregarded
column2: and apart from a few areas
column3: don't guard or patrol anywhere remarkable. The predator creatures are often copy-pasted to ridiculous extents in otherwise empty waters
column4: but can still be avoided simply by going around them.

column1: Land exploration is like pulling teeth. Journeying through blinding snow is exhausting
column2: as every location looks and feels the same. Land areas are open and repetitive
column3: with few interesting landmarks or terrain to make them unique. You unlock a hoverbike to help you navigate the terrain
column4: but then they make much of the terrain in those areas poorly navigable on the bike. At no point do you have an opportunity to open up the throttle and speed across the glaciers
column5: really making use of the mobility.

column1: We were here forever is a great new addition to the fantastic co-op series.
The games are asymmetrical co-op games
column2: that have you work together over walkie-talkies in order to solve puzzles. You are rarely in the same room
column3: and get glimpses of lore as you explore atmospheric castle set pieces.

column1: You get exactly what you'd expect here. Forever is more of the same
column2: but not in a stale way. Some puzzle styles will feel familiar
column3: while others bring fun and fresh ideas to the table. It's a great mix.

column2: you will be visiting unique looking areas that are in strong contrast to the drab bricked dungeons we're used to in the series. And we get a lot more story and cutscenes in this game
column3: for those itching to learn more about the world. It's done well
column4: and doesn't feel like it gets in the way of pacing.

column2: and the music always enhances the mood. I got sucked into the environment
column3: and got spooked or fascinated many times.

column2: the puzzles are pretty tough
column3: but you will figure them out with perseverance. However
column4: like in past games
column5: there are a few puzzles that really had us scratching our heads for a long time. The game can get quite tough at times
column6: with some time-sensitive puzzles
column7: or others that have you juggle a ton of information in your head at once.

column2: if you enjoyed the series up to this point
column3: I think you will have fun with this game too. I think the games have been growing in terms of quality and length with every new installment. And if you haven't played the series yet
column4: and enjoy asymmetrical co-op games
column5: (and don't mind possibly losing your friends over puzzle misunderstandings)
column6: then give the series a try!";20.0;1.0;88.0;4079.0;Posted: 10 May

YouTube™ Video: We Were Here Forever (ACTUAL Review) [PC]
I am still recovering from the trauma that a couple of the puzzles in the last We Were Here game caused
column2: but I can't deny I love the series.

column1: We Were Here is a series of co-op puzzle adventure games that play kinda like an escape room - the catch being that your friend is usually not in the same room and you have to relay information verbally in order to solve puzzles. It’s unique
column2: challenging
column3: and can oftentimes be frustrating if you’re stuck trying to describe what you’re looking at
column4: but it’s never not fun.

column2: just bigger and better in almost every way. The third game took my friend and I four hours to clear. This one though? It took us exactly double that time
column3: just over eight hours. The studio really went all out in expanding on the series and making it this full-length thing while avoiding some of the common pitfalls that such puzzle games fall into.

column2: the game is longer
column3: but it hardly recycles content. You are constantly going through new areas
column4: like a castle
column5: the snowy wilderness
column6: a dimensional circus
column7: or even an underwater cave system in a submarine. Half the excitement is waiting to see where the experience takes you next.

column1: You get your simple visual puzzles where you must relay strange shapes to your buddy using just vocal descriptions
column2: but also some creative riddle-solving puzzles and even puzzles that bend your perception of space.
for example
column3: was an audiovisual puzzle where I had to describe sound patterns and pitches to decipher what a giant squid was saying to us and then have my friend figure out the appropriate response in that same language. Despite my best efforts
column4: both my friend and I struggled with this one because we were too busy laughing at my poor attempts to recreate squid language - but that is exactly what makes this game so great.

column1: This is going to be very subjective depending on the players
column2: but my friend and I only got hard stuck once here and it did not feel as long as the last game - where we got hard stuck on multiple puzzles. Maybe the difficulty overall was toned down
column3: but there’s still a good sense of challenge here and it ultimately makes for a more engaging experience.

column1: You get this absolutely solid journey up to that point and then a final chapter that doesn’t even have any real puzzles in it
column2: instead just taking the form of a series of tasks before a cinematic and then the credits roll. It was disappointing considering the quality of everything that preceded it and left a stain on an otherwise solid experience.

column1: With the increased length of the game comes an increased focus on story elements. You don’t really need to play the previous games to understand it and honestly
column2: it’s such an afterthought to the rest of the experience that it hardly even feels necessary. It’s more so just there to connect these different environments together in a somewhat coherent manner
column3: but don’t expect anything story-wise to really stick with you after the experience is over.

column2: the game bugged out and phased my friend through the floor and ceiling - forcing both of us to reload the game to fix. Outside of that
column3: no other issues to report. The game looks fine
column4: has simple
column5: yet effective controls
column6: and runs well.

column1: We Were Here Forever is the best in the series yet. At double the length
column2: it brings all the crazy puzzles that the series has become known for
column3: just bigger and better. It’s creative
column4: has plenty of variety
column5: and is also challenging
column6: yet not unfair. Even if you have yet to play any games in the series
column7: this one is definitely worth a look
column8: it’s one of the better co-op experiences I have played in a while.

Songs of Conquest is a Heroes of Might and Magic inspired strategy game
column2: but with several unique twists on the old formula (which for the most part improve the game in my opinion).

column1: SoC has a gorgeous strategy layer where you manage and collect resources and build up your towns for unit recruitment. First and foremost SoC is a military conquest game at heart
column2: and economy is only a means to acquire better and bigger armies
column3: so this is not a Civilization game. If your heroes enter combat on the strategy layer (both against neutral mobs and other players) the conflict will be resolved in short tactical battles on a hex grid (usually 3-5 turns so the battles don't overstay their welcome). For those with little patience for easy battles - they can just be auto-resolved and a real ai-vs-ai battle is fought by the game ""in the background"" to deliver you the end results. You can also somewhat adapt the starting positions of your troops before entering/auto-resolving the battle.

column1: Many players will be familiar with Heroes of Might and Magic so I'll just list some main points how this game differs:

- There is no separate ""city screen"" and instead you build recruitment and economy/research buildings directly on the strategy map around your cities. There are limited slots so no single city can do everything. There are also different sizes from villages to towns to cities. More ""neutral"" economy and recruitment buildings are spread all around the map but they can't be improved
column2: you just ""flag"" them by visiting them with your army and then they provide their benefit to you.

column1: - The number of max. troops in a single unit is limited (can be increased via research
column2: imo better than in HoMM).

column1: - The number of units a hero (aka. ""wielder"") can command is limited but can be increased on level-ups.
- The number of wielders is limited but can be increased via the number and level of your owned cities.
- Mana (aka. ""essence"" which is mana with ""flavor"") for battlefield spells is generated each time a unit gets their turn in the turn order
column2: so your army composition and faction mainly determines your available spells. (Along with items and level-up skills so you can mix and match).

column1: - The spells are pretty varied and with some well-planned utility spells you can really swing the odds in your favor. The spells really open up your tactical options
column2: as it should be.

column1: - Each faction has 8 ""basic"" troops which can be upgraded to a significantly stronger (visually distinct) version for a total of ~16 troops per faction (currently 4 factions
column2: more are planned if the game does well) and then there's some neutral mobs like wolves as well. The upgraded version of a troop also typically has some form of additional battlefield ability that can be activated. The troop variety is decent
column3: most have a useful battlefield role to fill but some balancing will surely be done as the game goes through early access.

column1: - The tactical battles feature terrain height with higher terrain usually giving damage buffs to range and melee attacks. There's also obstacles
column2: but they only impede movement
column3: they do not affect ranged attacks.

column1: - In early access SoC currently features 2 campaigns with 4 missions each. Doesn't sound much but the maps get big quickly. I played both campaigns and they are already very polished (both gameplay- and story-wise) and the story really adds flavor to the varied factions and wielder characters so they become more memorable. It also serves a pretty good tutorial which then gradually transitions into a fairly challenging game. It's already good and I hope more will be coming if the game does well.

- There's of course things that need some improvement. Highest up on my personal list is simultaneous turns for multiplayer and even more balancing and more official maps (oh yeah there's a map editor and there's already maybe two dozen maps made by other alpha testers).

- The devs are amazing and responsive and based on my interaction with them during my time as an alpha tester I have no doubt they will manage to improve the game as we go forward with early access. There's even an in-build bug/feedback tool (press b-b-b) that grabs a screenshot and you can then describe and paint on it what's wrong and send it over so that it gets fixed (and they are quick!). That said the game is really well rounded already and you should not expect to experience many bugs.";51.5;1.0;346.0;607.0;Posted: 10 May

column1: Then Songs of Conquest comes along from a small indie company aided by Lavapotion as a publisher.

column2: again the question from those considering buying it is ""is this as good as heroes 3?"" will this fill the void that has been created by Ubisoft in not making a good heroes game for many years?

let me tell you that several elements are certainly the same. And you can already hear how that makes a lot of heroes 3 fans at ease. ""great! so I know what I can go into and let me enjoy a nostalgia trip""
and units with their own strengths and weakness

column1: - a focus on heroes that earn experience points
- you conquer towns and build them up
but let me also tell you that something is indeed different from the well-known Heroes 3 formula:
there is no fixed mana pool or pool of spell points. At the start of the game
column2: in every combat
column3: you gain points that you use to cast spells. But the big difference is these points (called essence) depend on the number of stacks of troops your field and their type. For instance
column4: if you place human archers you gain 1 ""order"" essence pr stack of archers. so if you have 3 stacks of archers you gain 3 order essence pr turn to cast spells.

column1: - army management and the number of slots you have for units.

This slides over to what is different in terms of army management. And especially the number of unit slots. In heroes 3 you could have 7 slots that you could place any units in. But in Songs of conquest
column2: the system is different. Here the number of unit slots is depend on skill choices and your hero. This means that if you want a bigger army than 3 stacks
column3: you have to use level-ups to unlock more unit slots. I currently have mixed feelings about this. It's a bit boring that you have to use your level-ups/ skill points just to be able to field more units
column4: without any other bonus. If the skills that gave you more units also provided some active skills that would for instance increase morale
column5: it would be a lot cooler.

column2: I do find it a bit limiting on the player that I cant have 5 stacks of archers to spread my units out which is a classic heroes 3 tactic to get more shots on the enemy.

column1: limiting the player's tactical freedom in this way isnt a good thing. But on the other hand

column2: this is my first time making an Early Access game review so if you have questions ask away in the comments. I was also part of the alpha testing for 2 years.

column1: The game follows the rules of Heroes of Might and Magic but less with the problems it had.
Such as teleporting around with a town portal or ""poor man's town portal""
column2: or having a high-speed unit on your army and waiting until you rush the enemy with Mass Haste.

column1: Or having or needing a limitless doom stack to kill your foes.
Heroes are wielders. There is no mana like in heroes however there is essence. Essences are gained from your units and with them
column2: you can cast spells. You gain more unit slots from level ups.

column1: No complex movement formula like in the Heroes series is based on unit movement and terrain. Units can buff themselves either by ability or passives.
There is no more hit and run tactics. However
column2: you could always plan and use a secondary wielder (or hero) to weaken the foe's main army. Losing your main wielder in some maps is never the end if you are able to create a secondary wielder. Units have stack limits. Hiring wielders requires you to have towns upgraded and to control wielders. As well as an option for what wielder you want to hire.

column1: There will be some familiar things from Heroes in Songs of Conquest. I have been enjoying this game and have over 500 hours in the game. Eager to see it grow.
They're also a map editor which I had fun making maps. Made 7 so far as of writing this. They may not be the best but was fun making them.
So far the campaign is of Arleon and Rana. Both have 4 maps each. They are both good at storytelling. It's rather similar to Heroes where you get a text about what is happening.
Each campaign explains how the faction was formed. What was the cause of it? Why are they doing what they are doing and their point of view?
My only critique is that they are short and I would love to have more maps as well as to know more about the world! However
column2: you will love completing the maps as you are rewarded with a song as well. It's amazing! I only have 1 issue with one map in Arleon but I can get over it here.

column1: I hope to see Loth and Barya be added. As well as story skirmish maps. I am looking forward to seeing more.

I will keep this short as I don't look into graphics into games. I barely take notice. However the pixel art is amazing! It's top notch and love every second of it. I only wish I was able to slow down the animations in battle.
It's not bad for me. My PC right now is:
Processor: ntel(R) Core(TM) i5-1035G1 CPU @ 1.00GHz 1.19 GHz
I play on medium setting (for all) and in windowed mode. It can run well in full screen as well.

They (the devs) listen to feedback and do check what people say. So don't feel discouraged to give your feedback and one more last thing. If you do encounter a bug in the game. Use the in-game bug report tool or press b three time. Helps the devs more then saying what happened on steam forums or in the discord. That is if you are able to report it. If the game crashes it's worth telling what happened.

Songs of Conquest has been delightful and fun. I enjoyed seeing the game developed over the 2 years and I hope it continues. The devs are amazing people and I only wish them the best. To me it is inspiring. I was a tester for over 2 years. There is more to come from the game. I have high hopes.";513.6;1.0;86.0;155.0;Posted: 12 May

column1: I've been mulling over the merits of this game for a bit in my head and couldn't quite place my thoughts in order until I read some reviews to get others' opinions.
The part of other peoples' comments that clicked most with me was the magic system. While playing
column2: I didn't really understand the magic system. That's because it is purposely obtuse for no good reason. It seems to me they changed it simply because they realized the rest of the game (except the city building aspect) was a lesser beat for beat remake of any Heroes of Might and Magic-like game to have existed. They felt the need to ""spice things up"". So they changed and castrated the ""magic"" part of Might & Magic. This essence nonsense not only isn't fun
column3: it's limp-wristed and a numbers game. Further
column4: it doesn't make any sense. Why do Wielders get their powers from the troops under their command? I suppose any half-way decent writer could come up with a mystical excuse
column5: but it's still stupid. Even more so from a gameplay perspective
column6: because it implies that the Wielder isn't a real character
column7: but an amalgamation of their troops. In fact
column8: that is a further problem I have with the game
column9: the Wielders don't feel interesting or powerful. They don't - feel - like they're in command. The army just exists to smash into another army
column10: and the Wielder is just their mascot.

column1: Another thing that others have touched on was something I didn't even notice. The lack of overworld magic. That's huge for a game like this. A large part of the strategy in these types of games was the magic you used in the overworld
column2: to buff your army
column3: or hinder your enemies. Now this is just... gone? And that's an improvement?

column1: So much for the ""magic"" part. Now let us speak briefly about the ""might"". It's... here. It's not really interesting either. You have stacks of units that do things and toss them at other stacks of units that do things. None of the units seem very interesting. Some are downright bad (Militia) and some do quite well (any undead unit). Many have said the battle maps are too small. I tend to agree. The maps are a bit smallish and the engagements are very quick. The terrain isn't interesting
column2: you generally have flat ground and you have high ground. Not much else. I will say one thing I very much do not like about the ""might"" system is the stack caps. This
column3: again
column4: is a balancing ""fix"" to the formula. All units now have a cap on their stack size
column5: which is very off putting to me. The whole allure to this type of genre is that it abstracted battles but still gave you the illusion that you were in command of a mighty force. In Heroes games you could have thousands upon thousands of troops under your generals. Each unit could represent many thousands of soldiers. Each bit of a damage to that unit was dozens
column6: if not hundreds
column7: of people dying each blow. Now? Eh... 50ish units per stack. Can be increased some more via research. What? Even Disciples games did a better job at creating an illusionary battlefield with it's four units than this. Because somehow
column8: Disciples battles
column9: while quick and streamlined like this game
column10: were more compelling than the battles here.

column1: The game overall itself is serviceable. The graphics
column2: for the style they were going for (pixel art) is fairly attractive... except for the horrific slo-mo close-up shots of the final hit in a battle. These can be turned off
column3: thankfully. The music is fine
column4: but nothing outstanding. The overall pace of the game is steady and a good homage to Heroes games. The city building is actually something I do like
column5: though I do wish it was somewhat less restrictive. The fact your city exists on the map instead of a separate ""city screen"" is a nice change. The game is a safe
column6: by the numbers tribute to the Heroes games. If that's what you're looking for
column7: you'll enjoy it... for a time.

column2: I never played Heroes of Might and Magic 3 - the supposed gold standard of this genre. I have played 4
column5: the Disciples games
column6: and a lot of ""clones"" in my time and I enjoy the format. Though I think the problem is that it has grown very stagnant and a lot of people are trying to basically reinvent the wheel instead of inventing the automobile. I feel this game is good
column7: but plays it safe and tries to ""balance"" the game; which always means to dumb it down and strip things out.

column1: I feel I gave this game too much leeway in trying to see the good and ignore the bad. As such
column2: I have crept past the two hour refund window and have to eat the rather somewhat steep price for what's on offer. I'd caution anyone else to wait and see how the EA develops
column3: but even then I think the fundamentals here are just too safe for a hallmark game; but just another Heroes of Might and Magic wannabe that is a flash in the pan and may even be forgotten within a year.

column2: if you're desperate for a Heroes-like game
column3: you'll find a decent one here. It takes many of the right ques from that storied genre and does them quite well (magic
column4: notwithstanding). But ultimately
column5: the question I ask myself and you should do as well
column6: ""Is there any reason to play this over those old games you probably already own?"" My answer would be flatly
column7: no. And despite all the work gone into this game and the nice little pixel art on display
column8: that is the most damning verdict of all.

column1: This Early Access game is a really well made product.

column2: graphics and style work perfectly

column1: - The UI is really intuitive and fairly simple but has good tool-tips for more detail
- Well thought out races x4 and a fairly simple economy that works (as in you never quite have all the resources you want or need)
It deserves a thumbs up review... but there are a few downsides and issues.

It is a little shallow on actual content for the price though at this stage - Only 4 races. Certain stuff like the magic system and battlefields feel a bit too compressed - magic is really ineffective and although they have tried to innovate (taking a bit from Age of Wonders mixing magic schools) - in reality the magic is underwhelming and a bit redundant in comparison to HoMM in part because by turn 2 everything is in melee anyway.

It also suffers some legacy issues exactly like HoMM - for example splitting your unit stack into single units is still overpowered - taking a whole AI stack's damage and providing a turn as a buffer. The AI also sadly cheats on economy and is very basic. There's no diplomacy or deeper interaction with the AI and so...
The mid-game feels a bit dull in terms of once an area is cleared of loot
column2: monsters etc the game just becomes a bit tedious - it would be great if they had more POI (points of interest) that you could grow and develop over the duration of the game - stuff that gives 'economy' wielders something to do instead of all charging for enemy towns or beacons just to end the game and 'win' ASAP. Something like an artefact workshop where a wielder can stand for a few turns to make or upgrade items seems a logical and technically simple leap.

column1: Another issue is the devs appear slightly non-committal on future content from what I've read. I understand not wanting to disappoint people or get hopes up too much
column2: but at the same time the premium price (for EA at least) does warrant quite a bit more content ... promised and ideally delivered IMHO. Relying on modders to pad out the game for them for free would be a mistake for me
column3: especially since everything is just so well crafted and polished thus far.

column1: Overall I'd give it an: 7.5 out of 10
Very solid foundations but needs (and I expect it to be) expanded upon.";12.5;1.0;4.0;96.0;Posted: May 14

column1: SoC takes all of the classic base-building
