column4: and tactical combat from HOMM and shapes it into a far more balanced and board game-esque mold. Gone are the limitless troop pools and legions of heroes. column1: The map design and expansion logic of the skirmishes often gave me the feeling of some kind of turn-based Starcraft with how its resources and build-sites are dispersed and managed

column1: I know some people have been turned off by SoC's magic system

column3: where your army composition has a tertiary effect of defining which spells will be available to you and how often you can cast them. And the opportunity to demolish and reshape my bases allowed me to experiment with these compositions in a synergistic way with the kinds of spell damage I wanted to inflict.

column1: A besieged kingdom loses its patriarch: in his place rises a hard-nosed daughter intent on proving her worth. With dark rumours of cultists
column2: power-hungry neighbours
column3: and restless Fey at the periphery the only question is how far she'll go to bring stability amidst a crumbling Empire.

column1: Amidst the fires in the desert
column2: an orphan slave is freed and returns to his home
column3: now with a thirst for vengeance against those who have oppressed his people for so long. It doesn't matter if the world is burning as well: his people will be free from the tyranny of man.

column1: Arleon (the remnants of the broken Empire) are the archetypal human kingdom but with some fun twists thrown in. Crossbows and longmen
column2: swords and shields - backed by oathsworn Fey that bring the fury of the forests into the mix.

column1: Barya are merchant-states to whom contracts are law and anyone can be anything. Great for discovering new technology. Also great for enabling slavery. Win some
column2: lose some. They rely heavily on firearms
column3: barriers and giant brutes - including an awe-inspiring cannon that will bring the end to any battle it sees use in.

column1: Rana are the slave-race of amphibians
column2: dwelling in the marsh amidst giant insects
column3: spiders
column4: carnivorous birds and an ominous threat you'll have to discover for yourself.

column1: The Barony of Loth is a kingdom in extreme decline. Their armies are gone
column2: their cities are ruins and no hope left. Well
column3: almost. You see: they're not just going to lay down and stay dead. The Barony of Loth will rise again
column4: even if its rotting citizens must slaughter the living to see its power rise once more. Cultists and skeletons abound in this cute twist on the typical Undead faction. Needs a tad more necromancy in-game
column5: though.

column2: a quick summary of the tweaks the game has made that have put it
column3: at least in my estimation
column4: as an excellent successor to the HoMM franchise.

column1: - Settlements have specifically sized building slots that ensure a single settlement isn't enough to build everything
column2: but it's enough to conquer the neighbours. This makes the game vastly less centralised than HoMM is. This is a huge positive in practice because it means many more settlements changing hands throughout the game
column3: as each map tends to have at least 6-8.

column1: - Stack caps. Gone are the days of 300+ crossbowmen that snipe you from across the screen. Now each stack has a certain number of units it can fit (increased via research): if you want more crossbowmen
column2: you're going to need to have multiple stacks of them. This enables a fair bit more variety in army make-up and also ensures that there is a hypothetical limit to how big a single army can be
column3: encouraging multiples.

column2: units have zone of control
column3: and there are height differences in the map that actually matter. This is pretty common among HoMM spiritual successors but is still worthy of note.

column1: - What magic you have is based both on your hero and on your army. Each unit you buy generates essence associated with them. A swordsman might generate Order
column2: for example. That then fuels Order spells. This is honestly a surprisingly fun premise that lets you build armies and heroes to compliment each other - like setting up a fireball mage with a bunch of destruction-essence units so they can start raining destruction with impunity. Though it also means as your units die you tend to have less and less magic to turn the tide. Gotta be careful. Nothing is truly expendable.
like stand-ins for mercury and crystals

column2: there are some bits that are... great

column1: It is a true successor of the genre and it improves it in almost every aspects:
1. Number of units and number of unit stacks is limited.
The number of units and stack a Wielder (a hero) can have is based on character skills
column2: which lessens the 1 stack of doom that plagued the genre. For example
column3: a starting Wielder can only have a maximum of 20 archers per stack and a max of 3 units stacks. As you gain level
column4: you can unlock new unit stacks and town upgrades allow you to increase the number of units a stack can have.

column1: 2. Town building is much deeper than in HoMM.
You are limited to a few numbers of building plot per Town level. Each plot is either Small
column2: Medium or Large and obviously
column3: stronger buildings require Large plots. Where this system shines is you can build multiple copies of a building if you like and you can even build smaller buildings than the plot (so Small in a Medium plot
column4: or Medium in a Large plot)
column5: which allows a character to say
column6: focus on one type of unit and maximizes its per turn production
column7: or even skip certain units you don’t want. And to top it all
column8: you can sell unwanted buildings
column9: so you can choose to build something only to fill the requirement of another stronger building and then replace the former with something that would actually help you recruit or upgrade the new stronger unit (like income-based building for example).

column1: 3. Combat feels about the same but is a bit improved.
You can dive in with the same nostalgia; most of the mechanics are the same. Your Wielder’s stats increase your units’
column2: units have a movement stat
column3: initiative
column4: attack
column5: defense

column7: instead

column11: you’d at least need specific units that generate the Mana you need to cast the spell and it would likely take a few turns to do so. There’s also the inclusion of Height which gives Defense
column12: Attack and Range bonus

column2: with some really good looking modern effects added in which doesn’t clash with the art style at all. The gameplay is what you expect: run around with your heroes based on a Move stat

column2: however
column3: I think it needs to critical QoL tweaks before I can fully recommend it to someone else:

column1: 1. The difficulty rating system for battles is CRITICALLY OFF. I've fought a fair share of battles from every difficulty level just to get a sense of what i'm dealing with and for starters
column2: (medium) difficulty should be labeled (Hard). Honestly
column3: every battle rating should be increased by one. That is
column4: Medium ---> Hard
column5: Hard --> Worthy
column6: etc. I've seen too many battles that were labeled medium and were completely unbalanced ensuring defeat.

column2: or more resources. The settlement economy is awful
column3: borderline 2007 recession when it comes to money it seems. Even when adventuring out to find additional sources of money & resources it never seems to be enough. On the other hand
column4: it seems that the AI always has just enough money to consistantly harass you with ""Medium"" level stacks. Even with (3) settlements making 5000 per turn I still couldn't recruit troops fast enough
column5: and eventually get harassed to death.

column1: 3. Please god allow us to click on our buildings and view resources when outside of our turn
column2: or for that matter simultaneous turn taking is better.
if too wielders are within a certain proximity to each other allow their troop stacks to combine during battle. Preventing this causes my ""troop transport' wielder to get targeted every time
column3: they die

column1: 5. Increase money resource values from farms/huts/etc from various factions. If I choose to forgo another building to increase my income

column1: That's all I got for now. Don't get me wrong

column3: 000 Zombies vs. 50
column4: 000 WW2 Soldiers

column1: I wanted to see how many units the engine could handle
column2: so I threw a truly outrageous amount of zombies into it. The map loaded up. All of the units appeared. My FPS was hovering around 4. Totally unplayable. To its credit
column3: it warned me it would be unplayable with that many units and even better is it DID actually load and run. So i quit and lowered the number of zombies to a more reasonable amount.
000 Zombies vs. 50
column4: 000 WW2 Soldiers:

column1: Wow. Not only did this run
column2: but it ran fairly well. Absolutely playable
column3: so here's how it went:

column1: I picked the map with the river with multiple bridges. Massive (that's 5 MILLION) zombie horde on one side
column3: 000 WW2 soldiers on the other
column4: placed 5
column5: 000 at a time at each bridge.

column1: The game loaded relatively quick and I pressed the button to start the battle. The zombies started splitting off and heading towards the nearest foes
column2: as did the soldiers. The problem here is that some of the zombies were far enough away that the soldiers crossed one of the bridges to attack
column3: losing their strategic advantage.

column1: The AI is fairly simple. Units will head for the shortest route to their enemies
column2: and then stand in a massive blob waiting to attack. Nothing too exciting
column3: but it works well enough for hordes of zombies.

column1: I let the game run on its own for a while
column2: and when I came back I found that the zombies had (unsurprisingly) massacred the soldiers that had crossed the bridge and were now slowly streaming their way up to the other bridges
column3: which were still holding just fine. It seemed that a relatively small force could hold off the zombies at a bridge
column4: especially since they don't swim. This is when I decided to take action and use what I think is one of this game's strongest features. RTS Mode.

column1: I peeled off a small company of soldiers from a bridge that was being held just fine and started marching them down towards the zombies that had made it through. I split the force into 2 groups and slowly worked them up towards the bridge
column2: one group moving while the other covered it. In a few minutes I had retaken the bridge. I made sure to issue an order for them to hold the position
column3: and I left them to defend. Turning my attention to the rest of the battlefield
column4: I found that some other soldiers were pushing too aggressively. They had pushed the zombies across the bridge and followed
column5: but if they attracted too many zombies they would get overrun and another bridge would be open for the zombies to attack. I quickly grabbed some units from another nearby bridge and had them fire on the zombies while I pulled the squad back across the bridge to hold that position. Perfect. All bridges covered
column6: no zombies advancing. At this point
column7: I had lost nearly half of my units
column8: while the zombies still numbered in the millions.

column2: I noticed that some areas were thinning out the zombies
column3: so I decided to go on the offensive. I grouped up some units from these bridges while leaving some to defend just in case
column4: and began advancing on the flanks of the zombies
column5: which were now split into two giant groups on either side of the map. I slowly advanced the soldiers
column6: and as they did more and more zombies would peel off from the groups at the bridges and come to attack my offensive line. Not enough though. I was able to slowly work through this group of over a million zombies and clear out this one side of the map.

column2: the mountains of zombie corpses were so high by the bridges still defending that I was worried the zombies would be able to cross the river
column3: which was now red. The entire landscape had been coated in blood. Low spots had practically formed new rivers that fed into each other. The landscape was being transformed with corpses and blood.

column1: Once I cleared out the top half of the map
column2: I issued an order for all the units up there to start marching on the lower half. It was only a matter of time before the zombies were wiped out
column3: and they were. The last bridge to be cleared of zombies was the one that had originally been overtaken. It had held out this entire time with the handful of units I had left there. Finally
column4: the last few zombies were picked off and I achieved victory.

column2: I could have just left the game alone once I retook the bridge that had been overrun
column3: and I probably would have won just the same. However
column4: being able to take control of these massive numbers of units and take the fight to the overwhelming opposition and WIN? That's awesome. I played the original game a bit
column5: but found it a bit dull after doing a few battles. Placing down a couple blobs of units and watching them run into each other for a while can only be fun for so long.

column1: In this game I was worried that it would suffer from the same issue
column2: just on a MUCH larger scale. RTS mode removes that worry. The game is still pretty slim on content
column3: but what has been achieved with this new engine... It's hard to really even put into words how it feels to see that many units on screen and have the game perform anywhere near acceptably. More than that
column4: to actually be able to issue commands to the units and have them (mostly) follow those orders? Wow.

column1: The engine is an incredible achievement
column2: and the actual gameplay makes me excited for where they could take this. RTS mode is the thing that brings what could be another dull unit blob-fest up to another level
column3: and I hope that the developers continue to expand on it. Could we see this turn into a full-fledged RTS? I hope so. If not
column4: there's still some great content here for battle simulations on a truly epic scale.";4.1;1.0;141.0;418.0;Posted: 13 May

column1: Ultimate Epic Simulator 2 is a revolutionary game
column2: and I am pleased to say that it performed as advertised in my session. I was able to get 3
column4: 000 independent units to fight in a single battle rather smoothly with my GTX 1660S
column5: while it struggled to even simulate 30
column6: 000 in the previous installment. That's 100x the improvement!

column2: it is very lacking in unit variation compared to the first game. One thing I liked about the previous game is having a hierarchy of unit types of a specific era. Take for example the Footman
column3: which has a superior variant - the Heavy Knight
column4: with the Golden Knight being the most powerful swordsman. This roster of units opens wondrous scenarios such as ""holding until stronger reinforcements arrive"" or ""mix skilled armies""
column5: like a well stirred salad.

column1: Another aspect is the variety in the unit themselves. The Footman may be colourful
column2: but it can get confusion which side they are on as their armour's colour does not correlate to their team. It makes battles between the same unit confusing and boring
column3: no matter how grand their numbers are. Units really have colours distinguishing their team
column4: otherwise it is only really fun to watch them fight different units.

column1: I think we can agree variety is important in battle sims. Otherwise
column2: we would just be watching the same thing over and over
column3: which is boring! The texture need some variety as well
column4: blood and grass look like checkerboards when viewed from afar. Maps also need more structures and obstacles
column5: otherwise they are the same flat map just with another coat of paint and limits scenario creativity.

column1: The game also has poor UI and game options. I understand it is in Early Access
column2: but I would really like to swap my y-axis camera controls and invert my RTS camera. Tips are also small and their colour blends with the background
column3: making them hard to read. Unit groups are also hard to find on both on map and in battle if they are only in the dozens or hundreds
column4: and teams do not have labels that show what units are in it. There is not even a menu for exiting the battle. The game needs better presentation; at the current state
column5: I find it too simple to be taken seriously.

column1: The RTS is a incredible feature
column2: I can command millions to a specific point smoothly and the units are very responsive! However
column3: it needs tooltips on the command
column4: it is confusing without explanation on hover. In addition
column5: I find it mildly infuriating that the command resets when another group is selected. Units also sometimes stop completely
column6: usually in groups. I suspect it's due to them getting blocked
column7: which suspends their all their order completely
column8: even the initial attack AI. This feature has great potential
column9: it just needs some auto-resume and toggles to make sure no unit becomes idle.

column2: the game has great potential to surpass every battle simulator in the market
column3: but its features are very bare-boned right now. I do hope the developers read this review and take in my suggestions
column4: I really do have faith in this game and want to see it succeed and become the Ultimate Epic Battle Simulator.";1.8;0.0;2.0;19.0;Posted: May 13

column1: There's also ""campaign"" mode but it's tabbed out and inaccessible for now. Barely any news on what it entails. column1: First of all. This review is based on my low playtime.
The idea of what rust can and could have been is good.
It's the current playerbase who turned this review the way it did.
Like I said. The game mechanics
column2: idea and execution actually is super cool. However as a new player you don't get a good first impression. Let me explain:

column1: So I loaded up the game with a friend of mine. I spawn on a beach and start running clueless around smashing trees and rocks. After a couple minutes I figured out how to build a tiny ♥♥♥♥.. I mean shed.
I go back outside to try to find my friend. At this point another player runs up to me. I say ""Hey I'm friendly
column2: I'm new to the game"" he then replies ""♥♥♥♥ you (Insert 3x racist words here)"" and proceeds to scream and play racist songs through his mic as he kills me.

column1: First I think that I was just unlucky to have met one bad person. I soon found out that ~80% of the players are like that.

Generally super toxic and unfriendly community. I left the game feeling annoyed more that happy(Which is what I'd like to feel after playing a game). Which resulted in me uninstalling the game and I've not touched it since.
Now some people may reply to this saying that this is just how this type of game genre is.
But I can say it's not. I've played SCUM
column2: Unturned
column3: DayZ ETC. And yes they had toxic people as well. But it was a much nicer experience as a new player to play those games over Rust.
